items.title: django 3.0 Incompatibility - "Invalid template library specified. ImportError raised when trying to load 'django_hosts.templatetags.hosts': cannot import name 'six' from 'django.utils'"
items.body:
I upgraded to Django 3.0 and on runserver this error is thrown

> django.template.library.InvalidTemplateLibrary: Invalid template library specified. ImportError raised when trying to load 'django_hosts.templatetags.hosts': cannot import name 'six' from 'django.utils' (/Users/OHEMENGTUTU/Dropbox/Asoriba/TECH/CODEBASE/AsoribaAPI/lib/python3.7/site-packages/django/utils/__init__.py)

I think it has to do with Django 3.0 dropping dependency "six"

items.title: django.utils.six module will be deprecated in Django 3.0
items.body:
Hello

I'm just trying Django 3.0 beta and found an issue with django-hosts package because django.utils.six will be removed from Django 3.0.

I don't know what would be the best move ?

Migrate package to Python 3 only ?

items.title: LOGIN_URL giving error when using django.urls.reverse_lazy
items.body:
I am trying to use **LOGIN_URL** with `django.urls.reverse_lazy` in **settings.py** file along with **django_hosts** installed and configured but it gives errors when using a view `@login_required` decorator or `LoginRequiredMixin`.

It gives error that `no reverseMatch found for 'login'` and also we cannot use the `django_host.resolvers.reverse` in the **settings.py** file since it gives error that `apps aren't installed yet`, we only need to use the hard coded url like `LOGIN_URL = //localhost:8000/login/`.

Is there any workaround for this thing instead of using the hard coded urls?

items.title: Can I insert django-debug-toolbar urls to every urls.py ?
items.body:
In `hosts.py`:
```python
host_patterns = patterns(
    '',
    host(r'admin', 'server.admin_urls', name='admin'),
    host(r'', 'main.urls', name='main'),
    host(r'app1', 'app_one.urls', name='app1'),
    host(r'app2', 'app_two.urls', name='app2'),
)
```

And now, I'm using debug_toolbar on every app like:

`app_one/urls.py`:
```python
urlpatterns = [blahblah~]

if settings.DEBUG:
    import debug_toolbar
    urlpatterns += [
        path('__debug__/', include(debug_toolbar.urls))
    ]
```

`app_two/urls.py`:
```python
urlpatterns = [blahblah~]

if settings.DEBUG:
    import debug_toolbar
    urlpatterns += [
        path('__debug__/', include(debug_toolbar.urls))
    ]
```

So, how to insert debug_toolbar urls to every urls mentioned by hosts.py ?

]
```
What am I doing wrong? Any help is greatly appreciated.

items.title: Django-Hosts Routing issue in Production
django-hosts requires *.dist-info metadata
items.body:
django-hosts raise an error if no *dist-info metadata is present

`pkg_resources.DistributionNotFound: The 'django-hosts' distribution was not found and is required by the application`

Possible actions:
- set `__version__` manually
```python
 __version__ = '1.2.3'
```
- wraps call into a try/except block
```python
try:
    import pkg_resources
    VERSION = pkg_resources.get_distribution('django-hosts').version
except Exception:
    VERSION = 'unknown'
```
- others?

After that's resolved, what do you think is the best way to retry the release? I thought of deleting and recreating the tag -- not sure if that might have some undesired side effect.

items.title: Django 1.10 compatibility
items.body:
I'm working on compatibility with 1.10. Just outlining here what changes need to be made.
- [x] middleware deprecated since 1.10
- [x] patterns deprecated since 1.8
- [x] string views deprecated since 1.8
- [x] django.core.exceptions.ImproperlyConfigured: No DjangoTemplates backend is configured - default TEMPLATE_LOADERS deprecated since 1.8, need to add TEMPLATES
- [x] Private api Model._meta.get_all_field_names() removed in 1.10

One side issue I have is that running tox, setuptools_scm doesn't install on py34 and I don't have time to go down that rabbithole.

items.title: host_url template tag deprecation warning for "on" keyword isn't raised correctly
items.body:
A warning is raised even if the url tag is used without "on", e.g. `{% url 'homepage' %}` (which relies on the `settings.DEFAULT_HOST`.

Also [the message](https://github.com/jazzband/django-hosts/blob/4b84fa58faac109cd845166b7cf9bf9cab821b08/django_hosts/templatetags/hosts.py#L142-L145) contains an uninterpolated %s, "The 'on' keyword of the '%s' template tag is pending deprecation...".

items.title: Adjust travis configuration to make the deployment to PyPI happen only once per build
items.body:
At the moment every build in matrix (for tagged commits of course) attempts to do the deployment.

Example:
https://travis-ci.org/jazzband/django-hosts/builds/96972410

As we can see `#101.1` has deployed the release to PyPI, while other six builds in the matrix failed to do so with:

```
Uploading distributions to https://pypi.python.org/pypi
Uploading django_hosts-1.3-py2.py3-none-any.whl
HTTPError: 400 Client Error: A file named "django_hosts-1.3-py2.py3-none-any.whl" already exists for  django-hosts-1.3. To fix problems with that file you should create a new release. for url: https://pypi.python.org/pypi
```

This seems to be easy to fix using [conditional releases](https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/deployment/#Conditional-Releases-with-on%3A). We just need to select one tox env that will be responsible for deploying.

More accurate solution would be to deploy only when all builds are finished. However, I have not found the solution for this yet.

The similar procedure can be done for other repositories under jazzband.

items.title: django_hosts.resolvers.reverse NoReverseMatch with wildcard regex
items.body:
Not sure if I'm missing something, but I'm having trouble using reverse on wildcard subdomains.
#### hosts.py

```
from django.conf import settings
from django_hosts import patterns, host

host_patterns = patterns('',
    host(r'www', settings.ROOT_URLCONF, name='www'),
    host(r'(\w+)', app.custom_urls', name='wildcard'),
)
```
#### app.custom_urls.py

```
from django.conf import settings
from django.conf.urls.static import static
from django.conf.urls import include, url

from app import views


urlpatterns = [
    url(r'^$', views.home, name='home'),
    url(r'^articles/', include('app.articles.urls', namespace='articles')),
    url(r'^events/', include('app.events.urls', namespace='events')),
    url(r'^partners/', include('app.partners.urls', namespace='partners')),
]

if settings.DEBUG:
    urlpatterns += static(settings.MEDIA_URL, document_root=settings.MEDIA_ROOT)
```

Now if I try something like:

```
from django_hosts.resolvers import reverse

reverse('home', host='wildcard')
```

I'm getting the error:

```
NoReverseMatch                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-2-e86d09f05052> in <module>()
----> 1 reverse('home', host='wildcard')

/Users/vitorfs/Development/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django_hosts/resolvers.pyc in reverse(viewname, args, kwargs, prefix, current_app, host, host_args, host_kwargs, scheme, port)
    167     hostname = reverse_host(host,
    168                             args=host_args,
--> 169                             kwargs=host_kwargs)
    170     path = reverse_path(viewname,
    171                         urlconf=host.urlconf,

/Users/vitorfs/Development/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django_hosts/resolvers.pyc in reverse_host(host, args, kwargs)
    119     raise NoReverseMatch("Reverse host for '%s' with arguments '%s' "
    120                          "and keyword arguments '%s' not found." %
--> 121                          (host.name, args, kwargs))
    122 
    123 #: The lazy version of the :func:`~django_hosts.resolvers.reverse_host`

NoReverseMatch: Reverse host for 'wildcard' with arguments '()' and keyword arguments '{}' not found.
```

Now if I change my hosts.py
#### hosts.py (removed regex)

```
from django.conf import settings
from django_hosts import patterns, host

host_patterns = patterns('',
    host(r'www', settings.ROOT_URLCONF, name='www'),
    host(r'test', app.custom_urls', name='wildcard'),
)
```

I can run:

```
In [1]: from django_hosts.resolvers import reverse

In [2]: reverse('home', host='wildcard')
Out[2]: '//test.testserver.local/'
```

Which is correct.

items.title: What about a new release?
items.body: Hi! I'm not sure if it's a right place for my question. Sorry about that. May, 6 - It was so long ago. Now, I get warnings in django 1.8. At the same time, master branch contains some commits fixing these warnings.

items.title: Update for removal of add_to_builtins() in Django 1.9
items.body:
Django 1.9 removes `django.template.base.add_to_builtins()` in favor of [a formalized API](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/releases/1.9/#django-template-base-add-to-builtins-is-removed).

To ease the migration, in `AppConfig.ready()` we could throw an error if `settings.HOST_OVERRIDE_URL_TAG=True` and  `add_to_builtins` isn't importable (Django 1.9+). The error would inform the user to add `'django_hosts.templatetags.hosts_override'` to the `TEMPLATES['OPTIONS']['builtins']` setting. I think it's probably better than updating the `TEMPLATES` automatically. This approach would allow us to eventually remove `settings.HOST_OVERRIDE_URL_TAG` too.

This would require removing `HOST_OVERRIDE_URL_TAG=True` from settings in order to silence the upgrade error then -- is it okay? I think most projects (not reuseable apps) don't try to support multiple versions of Django at once. If we need to be able to define one settings file that works with multiple versions of Django, then we'll need a different approach.

items.title: resolvers.reverse not pointing to domain, am I doing something wrong?
items.body:
`Django` 1.8.2, `django-hosts` 1.2

Config:

```
host_patterns = patterns('',
    host(r'', 'project.urls', name='root'),
    host(r'www', 'project.urls', name='www'),
...
```

Django shell example:

```
>>> from django_hosts.resolvers import reverse
>>> reverse("namespace:view", kwargs={'arg':8, 'pk':1}, host='www')
'//www/arg8/pk/1/'
>>> reverse("namespace:view", kwargs={'arg':8, 'pk':1}, host='root')
'///arg8/pk/1/'
```

Why isn't it `//www.domain.com/arg8/pk/1/`?

items.title: Django 1.8 deprecation warning for memoize
items.body:
Updating to django 1.8 shows the following deprecation warnings:

```
/python3.4/site-packages/django_hosts/resolvers.py:31: RemovedInDjango19Warning: memoize wrapper is deprecated and will be removed in Django 1.9. Use django.utils.lru_cache instead.
  get_hostconf = memoize(get_hostconf, _hostconf_cache, 0)

/python3.4/site-packages/django_hosts/resolvers.py:38: RemovedInDjango19Warning: memoize wrapper is deprecated and will be removed in Django 1.9. Use django.utils.lru_cache instead.
  get_hostconf_module = memoize(get_hostconf_module, _hostconf_module_cache, 1)

/python3.4/site-packages/django_hosts/resolvers.py:51: RemovedInDjango19Warning: memoize wrapper is deprecated and will be removed in Django 1.9. Use django.utils.lru_cache instead.
  get_host = memoize(get_host, _host_cache, 1)

/python3.4/site-packages/django_hosts/resolvers.py:62: RemovedInDjango19Warning: memoize wrapper is deprecated and will be removed in Django 1.9. Use django.utils.lru_cache instead.
  get_host_patterns = memoize(get_host_patterns, _host_patterns_cache, 0)
```

items.title: import reverse shadow issue
items.body:
`from django_hosts import reverse` 
imports deprecated module `django_hosts.reverse` instead of most important and actually desired `django_hosts.resolvers.reverse` function, basically module effectively shadows the import currently in `django_hosts.__init__.py`, namely `from django_hosts.resolvers import reverse`.
Considering the fact that `django_hosts.reverse` module will be removed in the next version anyways, nothing needs to be done. This issue is opened simply to record that `from django_hosts import reverse` will not work as desired until next release.

items.title: Document backwards-incompatible changes with post-1.0 releases.
items.body: Seems to be some backwards-incompatible changes made between the 0.6 release and the current one.  I resolved my issues by pinning `django-hosts==0.6` in my requirements.txt, but that's clearly not an ideal solution.

items.title: FAQ about cache middleware not threadsafe
items.body: http://django-hosts.readthedocs.org/en/latest/faq.html#does-django-hosts-work-with-the-django-debug-toolbar suggests to override `key_prefix` which is an instance attribute. Since middlewares are only instantiated once per process this does not work if threads are used (ie if a context switch happens somewhen between the assignment and the actual call to process request).

items.title: CSRF_FAILURE_VIEW for each host rule?
items.body:
Hi,

I'm having a problem which for 'csrf fail' on my api.host, the result is the 'csrf_failure_view' of my website.
The problem is that once it has some 'url' template tags (that don't have matching on the 'api' host, it gives and Internal Server Error (500).

Any way of specifing an 'host' independent setting for this?
Or maybe, creating an intermediate view that handles the domain part, and based on that result, shows and specific view for each domain?

Thanks for any help,
Felipe

items.title: empty regexp does not match
items.body:
if i use 

host(r'^$|www', 'custom_urls', name='www')

the empty regexp does not match
- for accessing site like http://project.com and http://www.project.com

items.title: host_name in host_url template tag as template variable.
items.body: Is it possible to pass host_name as template variable?

items.title: Settings depending on host
items.body:
Any ideas on how to import settings depending on the host?
Middleware approach is a good idea?

items.title: site caching
items.body:
I was having trouble, but finally figured out it won't work properly with site caching.  I needed to disable site wide caching, i.e. middleware django.middleware.cache.FetchFromCacheMiddleware.  

Any way around this or should I just switch to more granular, per-view caching?

items.title: admin routing
items.body:
hey great addon for django :)

but i have a problem:

i have 2 subdomains and all subdomains should be route to one admin interface

```
host(r'(app1|app2)/admin', 'urls', name="app1-or-app2"),                                                                                                                                                                                      
host(r'(app1)', 'app1.urls', name="app1"),                                                                                                                                                                                      
host(r'(app2)', 'app2.urls', name="app2"),                                                                                                                                                                                      

ROOT_URLCONF = 'urls'                                                                                                                                                                                                                      
ROOT_HOSTCONF = 'hosts'                                                                                                                                                                                                                    
DEFAULT_HOST = 'app1'
```

DO you have an idea?
thanks :)

items.title: Example in the docs
items.body:
Rather a question than an issue

in this example: http://django-hosts.readthedocs.org/en/latest/templatetags.html#host-and-url-parameters

shouldn't the username pattern go before the wildcard one (in a real-world setup) ?

items.title: host_url tag does not preserve server port
items.body:
Development server is running at http://127.0.0.1:8000/

Urls generated by host_url tag do not contain ":8000". Fixing the port in settings.PARENT_HOST can help, but not for tests.

I'm running tests with django.test.LiveServerTestCase (Django 1.4). Live server port can not be predicted, it would be nice to determine the actual port at runtime.

items.title: Cut a release?
items.body:
Pretty please? :heart:

(0.4.1 still carries the lingering Django requirement.)

items.title: Subdomains matching
items.body:
Hi.

I have some troubles with matching domains with levels more then 2.

Examples:
http://bb.aa.tt.localhost.ru:8087/
or
domain without subdomains:

http://localhost.ru:8087/

Maybe split host by . and apply host.compiled_regex.match to bb.aa.tt ?

items.title: Conflict with django-debug-toolbar
items.body: django-debug-toolbar does not work if its middleware placed before django-hosts middleware. On the other side - if django-debug-toolbar middleware is placed after django-hosts middleware - last one does not work.
